Consider the following state:

n : ℕ
ha : ∃ r, n = r + r
⊢ ∃ r, n ^ 2 + n = r + r

I know how to work with existence statements that are goals - I use use.

My question is how does one work with a hypotheses, eg ha above, that is an existence statement.

I'd like to do something like the following:

  • use k to instantiate ha, that is, going forward k represent an object that fulfils ha
  • then use rw using that k to do algebra with the goal until I can find an expression that satisfies that goal, completing the proof

There are a couple of similar tactics which do this, (all of which effectively are making use of the fact that Exists is defined to be this pair of things). obtain is subjectively the nicest one, namely obtain \<k, hk\> := ha will give you k as you expect and hk a hypothesis that it satisfies n = k + k.
rzeta0 has marked this topic as resolved.
